COMMISSION OF INQUIRY INTO
FINANCIAL TRANSACTIONS OF
DE-REGISTERED SINGAPORE
GENERAL EMPLOYEES' UNION,
SINGAPORE BUSINESS HOUSES
EMPLOYEES' UNION, AND
SINGAPORE BUS
WORKERS' UNION
(Statement by the Minister for Labour)


    The Minister for Labour (Mr Jek Yeun Thong): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to present a Report of the Commission of Inquiry into the Financial Transactions of the De-registered Singapore General Employees' Union, the Singapore Business Houses Employees' Union and the Singapore Bus Workers' Union.

    Hon. Members will recollect that on 11th December, 1963, I made a statement in this House concerning the setting up of a Commission of Inquiry to inquire into the mismanagement of union funds by the pro-Communist leaders of the de-registered unions. I mentioned then that while de-registration proceedings were pending against them, the leaders of these three unions were making desperate plans to withdraw large sums of money from the unions' bank accounts to finance the Communist united front campaign against merger and Malaysia. I also recounted to the House how these unions took advantage of loopholes in the trade union laws to sabotage measures taken by the Government to protect trade union funds in the interests of the workers. With the assistance of their legal adviser, Mr T. T Rajah, they contrived and succeeded in withdrawing $30,000 from banks in the second week of October 1963. When the Registrar of Trade Unions tried to ascertain whether this sum of money was properly and legally utilised, the pro-communist union leaders deliberately obstructed his inquiry. Even police investigations were hampered because of the sudden disappearance of the then General-Secretary of the Singapore General Employees' Union. These incidents caused concern to the public in

Column: 489

general and the workers in particular. Naturally they had good reasons to be disturbed. The so-called leaders of the pro-Communist unions have been claiming all these years that they were the genuine champions of the workers and had dedicated their lives to the cause of the trade union movement. But what some of the workers did not know, because they were really misled, was that these bogus leaders were dedicated only to the anti-national cause of their political masters. They were not really interested in promoting the industrial interest of the workers but just made use of the workers as political pawns to achieve their anti-national objectives.

    The public and the workers have a right to know the actual state of financial affairs in these unions. It is the duty of the Government to keep our citizens informed of the true facts concerning any matters of public interest. It was against this background that a one-man Commission of Inquiry was set up under the Inquiry Commission Ordinance by His Excellency the Yang di-Pertuan Negara on 21st December, 1963. Mr Tan Wee Kian, an officer of the Legal Service, was appointed the Commissioner. The Commissioner has now completed his work. In all, there were 38 sittings of the Commission. 116 witnesses were examined, and 324 exhibits submitted to the Commission. The report of the Commission was submitted by the Commissioner to His Excellency on 31st July, 1965. I now present a copy of this Report for the information of Members.

    The Report of the Commission reveals a shocking state of affairs in these three de-registered unions. Their officials have been found wanting and have not discharged the responsibilities imposed on them by union rules. This group of political activists in the disguise of trade unionists were found to have displayed a flagrant disregard of the statutory provisions governing the custody of trade union funds. The unions' system of accounting was such that it provided ample opportunities for the manipulation of financial transactions. Even the unions' legal adviser, the self-styled spokesman of the workers, Mr T. T.

Column: 490

Rajah, was found to be a party to the irregularities.

    According to the Report, in the transaction for the purchase of new union premises by the Singapore Bus Workers' Union, Mr T. T. Rajah, who acted for the vendors and the purchasers, undertook conveyance of the property to three union officials who were not trustees, although the rules of the unions specifically provided for all properties, movable and immovable, to be vested in the union trustees. In addition to the disappearance of the union officials, minutes and documents of the Singapore Business Houses Employees' Union, the whole Set of account books was also found missing, and deliberate attempts were made to frustrate the Commission's investigation and to cover the malpractices of certain officials. The Commission also found that huge sums of union funds had been dissipated illegally.

    The findings of the Commission in this respect, as summarised in its Report, are:

    (1) That in the case of the Singapore General Employees' Union -

    (a) Payments totalling $24,467 were unauthorised by the rules of the unions or contrary to the provisions of the Trade Unions Ordinance;

    (b) $29,847.95 were incurred negligently by the Executive Committee of the Union; and

    (c) $153,564.32 had not been accounted for.

    (2) That in the case of the Singapore Business Houses Employees' Union -

    (a) Payments totalling $13,550 were unauthorised by the rules of the unions or contrary to the provisions of the Trade Unions Ordinance;

    (b) Mr Foo Yong Fong, Mr P. Govindaswamy and Mr Tan Siew Chwee were found guilty of gross negligence in dissipating a sum of $26,901.30 contrary to the union rules; and

    (c) $35,654 had not been accounted for.

    (3) That in the case of the Singapore Bus Workers' Union -

    (a) Payments totalling $55,030.80 were unauthorised by the rules

Column: 491

of the union or contrary to the provisions of the Trade Unions Ordinance;

    (b) $2,535.20 was incurred negligently; and

    (c) $12,523.69 had not been accounted for.

    From the above, you will see that a total amount of $354,074.26 was either unauthorised, incurred negligently or had not been accounted for by these three unions over a period from 1st April, 1962, to 30th October, 1963. How much more was taken or misused by them nobody will know. This represents the largest amount of money the Communist union leaders had abstracted from the workers as far as records are concerned.

    Sir, this is not the first time that the pro-Communist union leaders are found to have misused trade union funds. Such things happened eight years ago. Just before the de-registration of the Singapore Factory and Shop Workers' Union in February 1957, a sum of $100,000 was unconstitutionally withdrawn from its bank account and the money just vanished into thin air. Members will recall that on previous occasions when I mentioned in this House how the bogus leaders of the pro-Communist unions illegally dissipated funds of the workers for purposes inconsistent with the objects and rules of the unions to the detriment of the unions and danger to the State, Members across the House, for obvious reasons, jumped up to defend their character and integrity and accused us of smearing them. Members will also recall that in the past, when the Government introduced legislative measures to investigate trade union funds, we were accused by Members across the House of adopting Fascist and dictatorial methods to suppress the unions associated with them. When they receive the Report of the Commission, they may read it in silence or play the same old tune. But one thing is certain, and that is that no amount of false accusations from Members across the Floor of the House and their friends will be able to alter the facts and figures contained in the findings of the Commission.

ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION
COMMUNITY CENTRE IN
NEW MACPHERSON
HOUSING ESTATE


    Mr S. V. Lingam asked the Minister of Defence if he will consider the construction of a Community Centre in the new MacPherson Housing Estate, which has a population of about 40,000 people, and when that Centre can be expected to be ready.

    The Minister of Defence (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government has no plans to construct a community centre in the new MacPherson Housing Estate in the foreseeable future. There are already in the Aljunied Constituency one standard type and one rural type community centres. In nearby Paya Lebar there are one standard type and five rural type community centres. If the residents of the MacPherson Housing Estate urgently want a community centre, they should club together and rent suitable premises from the Housing Board for this purpose. Now that we are an independent nation, social initiatives of this kind are to be encouraged. The attitude of expecting Government to be the universal provider is much to be deplored. It is a legacy of our colonial past.

    My suggestion to the residents of MacPherson Housing Estate is far from fanciful. In fact, a community initiative of this kind took place in Tanah Merah Kechil, Changi, where the residents clubbed together, built a community centre, and donated it to the People's Association. The residents of Changi are a sturdy breed. When the sea curfew imposed hardships on their fishermen, they did not sit on their haunches and wait for dole-outs by the Social Welfare Department. They organised a whip-round, bought food and provisions and gave these to the families of the fishermen. Their scale of donations is much more generous than the Government ration scale. It is sturdy self-reliance

Column: 493

of this kind that I commend to the residents of Aljunied, who surely cannot be in any respect less worthy than those of Changi.

DEBATE ON ANNUAL BUDGET STATEMENT


    Order read for resumption of debate on Question [13th December, 1965], "That the Assembly approves the financial policy of the Government for the year 1966.".-[The Minister for Finance].

    Question again proposed.

2.48 p.m.

    Mr Speaker: The Motion is now open to debate. I would like to remind Members that the debate should be confined to the general principles of Government policy and administration. Any matters of detail should be raised when the Estimates are being considered in detail in the Committee of Supply. Members are to remember that it is only the general principles of Government policy and administration that are subject to debate today.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, I wish to congratulate the Finance Minister on presenting to this House a practical and useful Budget. There are inherent difficulties facing any Finance Minister in budgetting for this small island State. We are a small nation with a population of some two million and we have no natural resources. We have a big neighbour with whom, in so many ways, we are still closely linked. For example, we share

Column: 494

a common currency. Because of this close link, any Finance Minister will have to look over his shoulder to see that any of his proposals will not invite retaliation from across the Causeway, or that any proposal will not be defeated simply because our neighbour is there. Let me give an example to illustrate my point. The income tax on companies is 40 per cent in Singapore. It is also 40 per cent in the Federation. Should we decide to raise the tax on companies to, say, 50 per cent, we have to make sure that the Federation do likewise. Otherwise, companies will move to Johore and conduct their business from across the Causeway. This little example goes to show the difficulties our Finance Minister faces in formulating economic policies for Singapore. It further goes to show how unnatural it is that Singapore and the Federation should be two economic entities instead of one whole.

    Be that as it may, we are now independent and sovereign. We have to manage our own affairs. The problems after independence are not quite the same as those before independence. We must find ways of meeting these problems. We must respond to the challenge. Even before Singapore joined Malaysia, Singapore embarked on a programme of industrialisation as the traditional entrepot trade was found to be insufficient and unable to create enough job opportunities for our fast growing working population. After Malaysia, however, industrialisation proceeded on the not unjustifiable basis that there would be a Common Market. With the separation of Singapore from Malaysia, the prospects of a Common Market become remote. Singapore by herself, however, forms too small a market to support an industrialisation programme. In order to industrialise effectively, an alternative to the Common Market must be found; in other words, we must find alternative markets to absorb the goods that our factories are able to produce. Unless these markets are found, our industrialisation programme will come to grief and we will face more than an unemployment problem.

Column: 495



    It is gratifying to note, therefore, that the Government is doing its utmost to find overseas export markets for our industrial goods. It is doing so on the official level by direct approaches to foreign governments. It is also encouraging private enterprises to look for overseas markets by providing suitable incentives like double deduction for tax purposes for market development overseas and for increased allowance for advertising. There is the further provision for an accelerated rate of depreciation for tax purposes for export-orientated industries.

    These measures proposed by the Finance Minister may be powerful incentives in normal times. We are, however, living in times that are not quite normal. Our industries are not long established. Most of them have just started production. Most of them too are pioneer industries. Pioneer industries enjoy special privileges, the most important of which is exemption from income tax for five years. Most of the new industries, therefore, would enjoy tax exemption for an initial period of five years and the double deduction in respect of expenses for overseas market development does not, therefore, benefit these pioneer industries. The same argument applies to accelerated depreciation, although in this case it is possible for manufacturers to postpone depreciation until after the first five years, i.e., after the period in which they are exempted from income tax.

    It is also well known that taxation is not a disincentive for capitalists. The reason is that as long as there is money to be made, capitalists do not mind paying taxes. What they worry most is the prospect of losing money. Exporting to overseas markets is a new experience to many of our industrialists. It is something of an adventure to them. To sell our goods abroad, we must give the foreign buyers some sort of inducement. We can hardly expect them to buy for cash. We would, therefore, have to sell on credit.

Column: 496



    It would be a great help, of course, if the Government could finance this export trade, especially for the small manufacturers. But this would throw an unbearable burden upon the exchequer. Financing the export trade is a more risky business than financing internal trade. This is especially so when we have to break into new markets overseas. So even if private industries can find the money to finance their exports, they would be slow to do so unless there is some sort of guarantee that their capital will not be lost. And here is where the Government can help. I have in mind, Mr Speaker, Sir, some kind of an export guarantee agency. This is some kind of insurance against default of payment by overseas buyers. At present, manufacturers, especially the smaller ones with a modest capital, are reluctant to export even if they could do so for fear that they may lose their capital. With this fear removed, we can expect to see a greater drive in industry to export. Many industrialised nations to whom an export market is important have this export guarantee system. Japan and the United Kingdom are two of the countries that come to mind. I confess that I have not made a study of any existing system and cannot, therefore, recommend how this system in our country should be set up. This task I shall leave to the experts in this field.

    I wish, however, to anticipate one criticism that is invariably levelled against any export guarantee system, i.e., that it invites reckless exporting by manufacturers resulting in a loss to the exchequer though not to the manufacturers themselves. This may be true in uncontrolled 100 per cent guarantee. But this defect can easily be overcome by guaranteeing not the full amount of the exports, but, say, 50 per cent. This will leave manufacturers to bear a proportion of the loss and will induce them to exercise caution. Further, exports can be controlled by commodity selection for export and quality control grading of export markets according to their risk, etc. But these are details which, as I have said, I shall leave to the experts.

    I also envisage this agency working hand in glove with our overseas trade

Column: 497

missions which will advertise our products abroad and provide us with accurate information about the conditions and needs of our overseas markets.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, finding overseas markets to support our industries has become an urgent task in our exercise for survival. I believe this proposal of mine can help, in however small a way, in this urgent task and I humbly beg to put it forward for the consideration of hon. Members of this House.

    Inche Mohd. Ariff Bin Suradi (Kampong Kembangan)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, I believe there is not a single Singapore citizen, whether from the working class or from the capitalist class, who is uneasy after the Finance Minister delivered his financial speech on the 13th December last. Usually after the policy speech by the Minister for Finance, people will be uneasy because of increased taxes. This time, not only are they very pleased because there has been no increase in taxes for the forthcoming year, but the taxes which were imposed by the Malaysian Government when Singapore was part of Malaysia have now been removed.

    Not only that, Mr Speaker, a point which further pleases the people of Singapore is that there are many other guarantees given by the Minister for Finance, like the setting up of more factories which will give more employment opportunities to the people, and the resumption of trade, particularly with Malaysia. This will bring prosperity to Singapore.

    But there is one thing about which the people of Singapore feel uneasy, and that is the attitude of the Minister for Finance in connection with back-pay. When he replied to a question by the Member for Telok Blangah on this matter, he reiterated his positive stand relating to back-pay. There is no change on that. The emphasis by the Minister for Finance can be equated to his giving a weapon to the employers to kill militant national trade unions by dilly-dallying over negotiations between the management and the trade unions. The Government will also employ this tactic to avoid reaching agreement between

Column: 498

workers and management. For instance, when a union puts up wage claims for better working conditions, the employer can deliberately dilly-dally over the matter. Or the management will first ascertain whether there is a claim for back-pay. When it can use this weapon provided by the Minister for Finance, then it will deliberately delay negotiations. Ultimately, union members who are strongly united and support the union will lose faith in the union, resulting in the union going defunct and this is the opportunity which the management has long been waiting for. But I do not know whether the Minister for Finance adopts the same attitude as the management towards the unions. When the unions can no longer represent the workers, the management will adopt policies at its own whims and fancies and this will result in the workers being oppressed by the management.

    Madam Chan Choy Siong (Delta)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, soon after our Finance Minister delivered his first Budget speech in the first independent Parliament of Singapore, he was received with great applause among the people of the various races in Singapore. All these people are of the opinion that this is a great assurance for the economic stability in Singapore. This is because in this Budget speech, we have been able to show our economic achievements which represent our national spirit and which augurs well for a bright future for our nation. And this again is a New Year gift for our people with the festive season just around the corner.

    As a representative of the people, Mr Speaker, I, on behalf of my constituents, would like to thank the Finance Minister for his Budget speech. I express my confidence in and support for this Budget speech in which our stability and progress are assured.

    Mr Speaker, looking at the Budget speech as a whole, we can see various salient features. I think it is necessary for me to point out these features. Firstly, in this budget we can see that the sum of some $537 million will be collected from revenue. Against this we will be spending a total of $505 million.

Column: 499



    So the balance is that we will have a surplus of some $30 million. This is the first point.

    The second point is that, because of our economic resilience and viability, we have not only been able to recover our losses as a result of Indonesian confrontation, but we have also been able to increase our national income by at least 2 per cent in the past one year. This is the second salient feature.

    The third point is that, as a result of Singapore's independence, certain retrogressive taxes have been repealed. These taxes were imposed by the Malaysian Central Government. Instead of these retrogressive measures, we have replaced them with some new measures which provide protection for our economic prosperity. From all this, we can see that with efficient and progressive new methods our economic future is well protected, and this will in turn bring about a reorganisation in the whole of our social order and improvement therein.

    On the other hand, this Budget speech goes a step further to show that our non-Communist democratic socialist Government is a well-organised and highly efficient piece of machinery. With its consistent policy and long-term objectives, it is able effectively to lead the people of our island State of 224 square miles towards a well-organised and better society, in which the standard of living of the people will be enhanced and improved with economic independence, which will bring about a more just, equal and prosperous nation.

    These are altogether the salient features that one will see in the Budget speech. What is more important is that, Mr Speaker, I would like to stress at this juncture that the contents of this Budget speech show that those theorists who are politically shortsighted are wrong in their view that they can stifle Singapore's independence with economic measures. They also show themselves that they are very stupid in believing that they can stifle our economic growth.

Column: 500



    Mr Speaker, I would like to give some facts and figures to prove my point. This will, of course, give you a better picture of the Budget speech. The average national income per capita of the working class in Singapore is as high as $1,300, which is the highest in the whole of Asia. Mr Speaker, compared with Malaysia, which is only $800 per capita income, Sabah - $700 per capita income, and Sarawak -$550 per capita income, we are also the highest in this region. The main sources of our national income come from these different fields: Commerce and Trade, 23 per cent; Industry, 18 per cent; Government services, 18 per cent; Armed Forces, 14 per cent; Agriculture, 18 per cent; Building Construction, 5 per cent; Tourism, 3 per cent; and Others, 15 per cent. The employment opportunities for our people come mainly from our commerce, transportation and other services which provide employment to 70 per cent of our people. In the field of industry and building construction, 20 per cent are employed. Agriculture provides for some 8 per cent of our employed, and others, 2 per cent. From all these figures, we can see that the economic policies of our Government are correct and on the right track. This is because, on the one hand, we can maintain our traditional trading centre and, on the other hand, we can go ahead with our industrial development programme. These figures also show that Singapore's commerce occupies a very important point in our economic structure. It is erroneous to say that it is only in times of prosperity that the Government is able to go ahead with its economic programmes. This is a very backward view which is not shown in our first Budget speech.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I am pleased to have learned from the Minister for Finance that for the first time the Government is intending to consolidate and improve upon our infrastructure with great sums of money, such infrastructure being necessary for our further improvement in social amenities and economic growth. All this will, of course, give our people a better standard of

Column: 501

living. I understand that it is the intention of the Government to spend some $976 million in the next five years, which is 60 per cent of the estimate for the purposes of economic development. Of this figure, a sum of $486 million will be spent on social development programmes, and these are all very good for our people, because this sum takes up about 32 per cent of the estimate for this particular Five-Year Plan.

    Mr Speaker, with regard to social development, I would like to mention in particular the programme in housing. Our housing achievements have not only won praise locally, but they have also boosted our international repute. This very well proves that our country is going on the right track and that our Government has the determination and verve to face all types of difficulties and challenges in order to find a way out for our people through all these economic challenges and difficulties.

    Mr Speaker, the reasons for saying so are very simple and clear. You will remember that when we first came to power in 1959, many, many people were without decent housing and even experts were of the opinion that our housing problem was difficult to solve, because at that time there was an acute shortage of houses in Singapore and whatever programme for housing development we had, it would not be possible to catch up with the growth of our population. But the facts before us today show that all those fears were actually unfounded and that the housing programme of the Government has been very successful all along.

    Mr Speaker, you can see that many, many question marks have turned into a lot of exclamation marks in praise of our achievements. Now we have come to a stage where we are able to build one unit in 45 minutes. All this goes to show the overall success of the housing programme of the Government.

    Mr Speaker, you can see how successful we are. A development officer of E.C.A.F.E. said that the housing programme in Singapore provided by the Government in respect of low-cost

Column: 502

housing has been shockingly and surprisingly successful and that this was a very massive programme - in fact, the greatest of its kind in the whole of Asia.

    Mr Speaker, our success can be seen in the new housing estate now in Bukit Ho Swee which was devastated by a big fire in 1961 in which about 16,000 people were rendered homeless. The Government then took up the challenge to build houses for these people. On 1st February, 1960, the Housing Board was set up and it took over our housing development project from the former Singapore Improvement Trust.

    Mr Speaker, let us take note that the people of Bukit Ho Swee have been lucky in that in a short time they are able to enjoy decent housing provided by our Government. Against this background, let us take a look at the history of the former Singapore Improvement Trust. In its 32 years of existence, it was only able to put up 21,689 units of houses and shophouses. This shows that the former Lim Yew Hock and the colonial governments were not only inefficient but also incompetent. Against this historical background, we will take a look at our achievements. We have been able to put up altogether about 52,206 units of houses since 1959. This figure includes flats as well as shophouses. The break-up is as follows: in 1961, altogether 7,320 units of low-cost houses were built for our people; in 1962, we built 12,230 units; in 1963, we built 10,085 units; in 1964, we built about 13,280 units. Since the Government came to power, we have been able to put up a lot of flats and blocks of houses in various areas in Singapore, particularly in Queenstown, Bukit Ho Swee, MacPherson, St. Michael's, Alexandra, Jurong new town, Kim Keat, Geylang Serai, Toa Payoh, Kallang, Selegie Road, Onan Road, Toa Payoh South, etc. In these areas, we have been able to put up altogether about 44,345 units of houses in order to enable our people to live in housing estates. The Government also provides them with housing subsidies. The figures are as follows: in 1960, the subsidy provided was $2.1

Column: 503

million; in 1961, the provision was $2.1 million also; in 1962, it was $4.2 million; in 1963, it was S6.5 million; in 1964, it was $9.5 million and for 1965 it will be $9.7 million. All these figures show the amount of housing subsidy provided by the Government for the people. So the Government has not only solved the acute problem of housing shortage but has also provided the people with social amenities in the housing estates, such as schools, clinics, playgrounds, etc.
